content:
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
laboratories. The National Centre should a be screen or sorting agency (not a barrier) between the International Centre and the country's peripheral laboratories; and so the International Centre's influence, ideally, would reach out to the peripheral laboratories only through the National Centre. It follows obviously from this that is it essential that the laboratory selected to serve as a National Centre should be one which has easy contact with local or peripheral laboratories throughout the country.
While, as suggested in the paragraph above, the International Centre's official scientific relations should in principle, and usually in practice, be only with the National Centre and not with the country's peripheral laboratories, there should, of course be on interference with free scientific intercourse between the International Contre and any other laboratory in the world at the undisputed idscretion of the workers concerned - providing that this does not hinder orderly development of the subject or of central laboratory facilities in the country.
As has already been empasized above it is, of course, the prerogative of the government of euch country alone, and not of HO or of the International Centres, to select and appoint the particular laboratory which is to serve as its National Salmonella Centre or Its National Shigella Centre. However, it might perhaps be helpful to governments contemplating the designation of n National Salmonella or Shigella Centre if a detialed description could be made available of the way in which a National Simonella Centre operates in one particular country, as an example. Therefore a contribution of this nature, written by Invitation by Dr Joan Taylor, Director of the Salmonella Reference Laboratory, London, England, and entitled "The Function of a National Salmonella Centre", is reproduced below. In presenting this as an example it is not in any way suggested that the National Salmonella or Shigella Centre of every country should be organized on exactly the sume lines, since there are, of course, wide differences between one country and another in respect of the structure of their health services and in other relevant circumstances.
"The way in which the Salmonella Reference Laboratory has approached the Salmonella problem in the United Kingdom may not be es entially different from the approach made in other countries. This is a small country with a dense population, provided with good lines of communication to all but a few remote parts of Scotland and the outlying Islands; there is integration of all medical services as a result
國史饭 Academia Historica
